div.p: The South Carolina Department of Education (SCDE) is working closely with the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) and other agencies to ensure local school districts, parents, and students have the most accurate and up-to-date information regarding COVID-19 (commonly called coronavirus). Please visit DHEC's dedicated website for important information concerning the virus and its impact on South Carolina. Have a general question about COVID-19? Call the DHEC Care Line at 1-855-472-3432 between 8 a.m. and 6 p.m. daily.

u.strong: Free Internet for Students Impacted by School Closures

ul.li: AT&T: two months of free service to new access customers who order by April 30, 2020. It will then be five dollars a month or 10 dollars a month after the free two months, depending on speed. The company said it will expand eligibility for households participating in National School Lunch Program/Head start. Visit att.com/access for complete information and to apply.

Charter/Spectrum: Charter will offer free Spectrum broadband and Wi-Fi access for 60 days to households with K-12 and/or college students who do not already have a Spectrum broadband subscription and at any service level up to 100 Mbps. To enroll call 1-844-488-8395. Installation fees will be waived for new student households.
Chesnee Communications: call 864-461-2211

Comporium: Comporium is offering 60 days of free service to new customers in homes where a student lives. Comporium is also waiving installation fees and their normal security deposit process. To find out more, please contact Comporium at 1-888-403-2667 or chat with a member of their customer service team at www.comporium.com. Customers living in Comporium’s Midlands service area should call 1-800-258-7978.

FTC: FTC is offering 60 days of free internet service and free installation to homes within FTC’s service area that are the primary residence of a student in kindergarten through high school, technical school, college or in graduate school; and who have not been an internet customer with FTC for the past 90 days. Call 888-218-5050 and press '4' when prompted, visit FTC.net and begin a chat session by clicking on the bottom right of the screen, text 843-382-8398, or email contact@ftc.net.
Hagray: visit Hargray.com/freeinternet, or call 877-427-4729
Home Telecom: visit HomeSC.com/Connect, or call 888-746-4482
PRTC: Walterboro customers call 843-538-2020, or St. George customers call 843-931-1212
PRTC (Piedmont): call 864-682-3131
TruVista: call 800-768-1212
WCTEL: call 864-446-2111, visit wctel.com/covid-19/

Xfinity/Comcast: New Internet Essentials customers will receive two free months of Internet service if they apply by April 30, 2020. After promotion, regular rates apply. For all new and existing Internet Essentials customers, the speed of the program’s Internet service has increased to 25 Mbps downstream and 3 Mbps upstream. Households with outstanding debt owed to Comcast may be eligible for Internet Essentials. They are waiving this qualification if you apply and are approved by 5/13/20. After 5/13/20, standard eligibility rules apply. Additional details available at https://www.internetessentials.com/.

div.p: The SCDE's Office of Special Education Services has developed and is continually updating resources, materials, and responses to frequently asked questions about providing special education to students with disabilities during the COVID-19 pandemic and statewide closure of schools. The below website includes information for parents, educators, and schools.

strong.a: COVID-19: Services to Students with Disabilities Website

p.a: Talking to Children About COVID-19 (Coronavirus): A Parent Resource

br.a: VirtualSC Supporting Digital Learners

br.br:
As we each do our part to safeguard the physical health of our families, friends, coworkers, community, and selves, we must also do the same for our mental health. To help, the South Carolina Department of Mental Health (SCDMH) has gathered some tools and resources to help cope with the stress and anxiety during these uncertain times.
S.C. Department of Mental Health Resources to Help Cope with Coronavirus

p.strong: What should I do if my child exhibits symptoms?

br.br: Contact your doctor, a local public health clinic, or hospital. DHEC is currently advising that individuals who have traveled from affected countries/areas and have a fever, cough, or difficulty breathing should seek medical care, and should contact their healthcare provider and inform them of their travel history before going in.

hr.p: Several South Carolina health systems are offering virtual visits for free to anyone experiencing COVID-19 symptoms in South Carolina. In order to access the free consult, Use the promo code COVID19.
McLeod Telehealth: https://www.mcleodhealth.org/services/care/telehealth/
MUSC Health Virtual Urgent Care: https://campaigns.muschealth.org/virtual-care/index.html
Prisma Health Virtual Visit: https://www.prismahealth.org/virtual-visit/

Roper St. Francis Healthcare Virtual Care: https://www.rsfh.com/virtualcare/
When should I seek medical attention?
If you or a family member develop emergency warning signs for COVID-19, call 911 for immediate medical attention. Emergency warning signs include*:

ul.li: Trouble breathing
Persistent pain or pressure in the chest
New confusion or inability to arouse
Bluish lips or face

p.em: *This list is not all inclusive. Please consult your medical provider for any other symptoms that are severe or concerning.

span.strong: What can I do to prevent COVID-19?

br.br: We all have the responsibility to protect ourselves, our families, friends, and community. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has provided tips on how to protect yourself and your family. You can also:

ul.li: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds especially after you have been in a public place, or after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
Cover your cough and sneezes with a tissue or use the inside of your elbow.
Practice social distancing.
Stay home if you’re sick and avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Clean AND disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily.

br.br: Beginning Tuesday, March 24, SCETV will modify regularly scheduled programming for three days each week to offer specific pre-K – 12 resources between the hours of 8 a.m. and 6 p.m. The three days selected may vary from week to week. Program modifications will take place throughout the duration of school closures and will address a wide variety of content areas. Educators and parents will have access to supplemental lesson plans and curriculum materials to facilitate meaningful use of the content.

li.a: How to Access ETV from home

ul.li: Check out Knowitall.org for content by subject and grade level.
Our library of PreK-12 content is all posted online!
Our Kids Channel is available online 24/7
You can live stream from your computer and the SCETV App.

br.br:
VirtualSC, South Carolina's free, state-sponsored online program is offering free educational resources to our students, parents, and teachers while our schools are closed.
Please visit virtualsc.org/resources to find a variety of resources, including: test prep for national exams like SAT, ACT, PSAT, Advanced Placement exams, personalized math programs for 6-12th grade students, free educational videos , and more.

hr.p:
During a special called meeting on March 24, the State Board of Education (SBE) approved emergency exemptions related to Spring 2020 clinical and field experiences. The purpose of these exemptions is to hold harmless Spring 2020 student teachers and move them forward to successful completion of educator preparation programs, certification, and employment.
The policy also addresses flexibility for clinical experiences leading to initial or add-on certification in service and leadership fields and for field experiences (prior to student teaching) that cannot be completed in school settings at this time.
On Friday, March 20, 2020, Superintendent Spearman requested and received approval for an emergency regulation (Regulation 43-40 COVID-19 Waiver and Suspension of Provisions) that allows her to waive or suspend provisions of regulations in Chapter 43 that may be impacted or affected by the COVID-19 State of Emergency in South Carolina.
The Certification and Educator Preparation teams in the Office of Educator Services continue to work on additional emergency provisions that may be necessary to support educators and certification applicants. Please know that we will communicate as we determine and implement additional measures to address the impact of COVID-19 closures, including Praxis testing centers and fingerprinting offices.
The Office of Educator Services has created a Certification Updates webpage where we will post information for applicants and educators. The quick link to that page is https://ed.sc.gov/certificationupdates. Our staff members are now working remotely; yet, we remain available to assist applicants and educators. Although call center and walk-in services are suspended at this time, individuals may communicate with us through email at certification@ed.sc.gov or altcertification@ed.sc.gov.
Educators at the S.C. Department of Education have developed remote learning resources that can be used by teachers across all grade levels.

The links and resources included were both developed internally and vetted from outside sources for use by school districts as instructional resources. Resources will continue to be added as they are developed and vetted.

The PersonalizeSC Community, created in partnership with KnowledgeWorks, is an online tool that enables easy access via a mobile app, web browser or email. Through the PersonalizeSC Community, educators can find and upload learning resources, connect with other educators and engage in online discussions.
We know that not all students have access to computers or Wi-Fi at home and want to work with you to deliver low-tech and no-tech options to ensure every child has access to meaningful learning and social-emotional support during school closures.
Visit tinyurl.com/JoinPersonalizeSC to register.
Makin’ It Personal: A #PersonalizeSC Podcast on Remote Learning

p.strong: In the event of a severe pandemic, will the U.S. Department of Education allow flexibility for federal K-12 requirements or deadlines?

br.br:
On March 17, 2020, Superintendent Spearman sent a letter to U.S. Department of Education Deputy Secretary of Education, Mick Zais, indicating South Carolina’s intent to suspend federally required assessments and giving notice of submitting additional accountability measure waivers. On March 20, 2020, the U.S. Department of Education released a form for states to request such waivers. The SCDE completed and submitted the waiver form on the same day, and the U.S. Department of Education reviewed and gave South Carolina approval to suspend assessments and waived certain accountability measures.
U.S. Department of Education Approval Letter

p.strong: Who is responsible for requesting State, LEA, or school flexibility related to federal K12 requirements or deadlines?

br.br: While States, SEAs, LEAs, and schools (through their LEAs) can request a waiver, the Department strongly encourages States to coordinate waiver requests within the State. States should provide guidance and a process for LEAs and schools to work with the State to request waivers. If in the event of a severe pandemic, a State believes a waiver may be needed, the State should immediately contact the Department.
